subject: Worldcon Looms
event:
Tomorrow morning it's off to Reno for worldcon.

Worldcon is my favorite con, and Reno promises to be an especially good one.  They have a very experienced committee and, by all reports, a great facility.  If the fannish ghods are good (and I sure hope they are), we will not be vexed by any of the hotel problems that troubled the recent worldcons in Melbourne and Montreal.  

All that being said... I sure wish Renovation was being held on Labor Day weekend.

Two reasons:
       (1) Labor Day weekend is the perfect worldcon weekend, hallowed by decades of tradition (yes, I know the con originally started on July 4th weekend, but that was before I was born, and not relevant), and worldcon (and worldcon alone) belongs on that weekend,
       (2) it would give me more time to rest.  It seems as though I just got back from San Diego Comicon and my nine-city book tour (maybe because I DID) and now I'm on the road again.  It's too damn soon.  San Diego has become an increasingly important part of the annual con circuit for any professional writer; worldcon needs more distance from it, to give us poor pros a chance to catch our breath, unpack our suitcases, maybe do a laundry.

But Renovation is when it is, and I'm not about to miss it.  

So off I go, weary or no.  See you there.

The road goes ever on and on...

comments.article: I'm looking forward to it too! See you there!
I am super excited! Can't wait!!!

I don't suppose you'd ever make it down to New Zealand, but have you ever been to Australia??

*crosses fingers you might one day* :)

Uh... I've been to New Zealand twice and Australia four times.

I expect I will return to both, eventually.

Hooray for Reno!

Looking forward to it.
ah...and then again, we are older now.....we can't do the things we did when we were younger...! Good luck, and enjoy Worldcon.....I wish...I had such a luxury.

Down from the door where it began.


Hooray for Reno indeed.
It's my understanding that Worldcon does this so as not to try and compete with DragonCon, which is a much bigger con for many of the same Vendors Worldcons want to court.

There are a bunch of reasons for going a bit earlier than Labor Day weekend, and avoiding Dragoncon is only one of them. August is a lot easier for people who have children, and for teachers. Convention centers tend to be under-utilised in the holiday season, so the rates are cheaper. If your convention finishes on a public holiday, it can make it more difficult and/or expensive to get things done in the tear-down.

comments.upictitle: Jenna: Sugar and spice and all that
comments.article:
Wish I could be there.

I was at a small local con and spoke with a pair of good friends of yours!
I dunno why you'd want Worldcon on Labor Day weekend. Putting it in direct competition with DragonCon, seems like a good way to kill it off. Almost impossible for them to get any guests.

Dragoncon belongs in July, its original dates.

By moving to Labor Day, Dragoncon broke decades of fannish tradition. Labor Day belongs to worldcon.

There are still some of us old-timers who will never go to Dragoncon so long as it remains on Labor Day (I was once a guest at Dragoncon, yes, but back when it was on its original dates).

comments.subject: we have no problems getting guests

comments.article:
The road goes ever on and on...

...down from the door where it begun?

Yep, it's stuck in my head now!

It's my first Worldcon (or ANY con, for that matter), and I am thrilled and excited to go. I'm attending the writers workshop, and was only worried that the time might conflict with your autograph session. However, the universe is smiling on me, so I hope to see you there! My only question is why aren't you hosting a literary beer session? I know, there's only one of you...
Pandora Swift
comments.subject: Hope to see you there!

comments.article:
I so wanted to go to San Diego Comic Con, but i missed it this year. Hopefully, i will go next year. :)


I finished A Dance with Dragons, and now I do not know what else to read. I loved the books so much.

Do you have any suggestions for good books to read? I apologize if this has been asked a gazillion times.
Take a break, rest up. Than crawl into your man cave and write for pleasure. Us fans cant have you getting burnt out. :) I hope your Journey to Nevada was nice.

At least the road to Reno is short.

And we are very extremely quite enthusiastically appreciative of the Winds of Winter sample chapters that it's been rumored that you may be reading. =)
Is the black cat Arya chases, catches and kisses before releasing in the Red Keep the kitten (now grown up) which belonged to the little princess murdered by the Mountain?
comments.subject: Arya's Black Cat

comments.article: It's never been said, but I've always liked to believe he is poor Rhaenys's kitten
comments.subject: Re: Arya's Black Cat

comments.article: I just wanted to send a note to tell you how much I loved the latest installment, even the book itself is amazing, such beautiful Dragons on the cover. It was like going home to old friends, my only angst is waiting to see what happens next in the lives of those we love. ;-) Thank you so much!!!
comments.subject: Dance with Dragons

comments.article:
I hope you enjoy! I am not sure who to direct this question to so if this is the wrong place please point in the right direction:

Seattle has a small geek convention called Emerald City ComiCon. I think it would be a great experience for everyone if you were to join us. Would you consider contacting the staff there about appearing?
comments.subject: Question

comments.article:
actually, the way to do this is to have the convention contact George.

These days, we're booking him three years out.
comments.subject: Re: Question

comments.article:
In a million years I would never have thought I would 1. join a blog site 2. actually leave a comment or 3. even think about going to one of these conventions never mind actually being jealous that I cannot!
I also cannot believe that the one time George was anywhere close to where I live - Burlington Mass - I was away on vacation! Come to Boston George!

I would love to attend a con but ever since my acrophobia diagnosis I can't leave my property.

I am wondering... are there any restrictions on recording video? In the past I've dispatched proxies (usually escort service ladies who cater to people with disabilities) with some of my video equipment to livestream events I'm unable to attend. Essentially I hire someone to lifecast for me for a few days. If you've ever seen the British movie Freeze Frame, you know the deal, though take the place of a creepy guy with an attractive escort.

She'd be a topic of conversation at your bwb after parties for sure.
comments.subject: Have a great time Ser!

comments.article: will ask George about this - the big issue is that he always requests that no one record his readings, yet people do and they end up on YouTube, which is not cool when he specifically asks people to not do that.
comments.subject: Re: Have a great time Ser!

comments.article: Random question but was the idea of the Eyrie partially derived from Castle Dracula? I was reading Dracula again and there are some resemblances between the two. Just wondering...
comments.subject: The Eyrie

comments.article: Ha ha!  Did you see your Daily Show reference?  Be grateful for the free hot chai!
comments.subject: Daily Show

comments.article:
First, thanks so much for writing this series, it's exactly everthing a novel of this genre should be. Great story and wonderful characters.
Second, I am a big listener of books, not having the time to read much, and appreciate the talents of Dotric and Lee for your first four books.
I know the authors don't always have a say in who reads their books, but I would love to hear yours performed by Phil Gigante. He is an outstanding narrator, Multiple Audie award winner including 2010's Best Sci Fi winner for Harry Harrison's Stainless Steel Rat. Phil reads many genres of books and does outstanding work in all of them. He has a huge fanbase including the Moning Maniacs (Karen Marie Moning) for her Highlander and Fever series books. If you haven't already, take a moment to listen...it would be great to have a favorite writer read by a favorite reader.
Continued success in this series as in all your endeavors.
comments.subject: Narration

comments.article: I saw you a number of time at SDCC, it was great to see you after all these years. I used to go to your signings way back when for your Sci Fi and Horror books (Fevre Dream, Songs the Dead Men Sing, Night Flyers, The Armageddon Rag, .. etc ) I never read the "a Song of Ice and Fire" novels until GOT appeared on HBO and the show brought back my fond memories of reading your books. I'm all caught up now with the novels now :) . I went to the GOT panel and you were great moderating the panel. I also saw you at the Wild Cards panel, but I admit I was there for the next show like many of the people in the audience (Castle) , you were great in handling the crowd and probably got quite a few new readers for the Wild Card series.
comments.subject: San Diego Comic Con

comments.article:
I don't know if GRRM is going to read this, but I'd like to say how A Song Of Ice And Fire inspired me these last two months with the full 5 books.

I have this thing about taking some scenes in books, shows and extracting some kind of significancy of them to the difficulties of my life and such.

˜˜˜˜˜˜SPOILERS BELOW˜˜˜˜˜˜˜

The scene where Bran is thinking how sad it is to not be able to hug Merra like someone who can walk, it made me think about the difficulties that we face in our lives and how we deal with them, like being alone and accepting what we are, really interesting.

The Faceless Men training for Arya was also something that I took for being able to control ourselves and the possibility of someone getting better and changing their lifestyle.

And the last Victarion Greyjoy chapter where he shows how he is mercyless, confident about his beliefs and willful about surpassing the difficulties in his way to achieving his dream.

Pretty sure this is uninteresting for most of the readers, but It's great for the autor to know that is books are helping people in surprising ways ;D

Greetings from Brazil, Cheers!

I doubt we'll be able to afford going to Chicago next year, since we already have 2 more expensive trips we will need to save for earlier in 2012.

Maybe 2013 will finally be our year to make it to Worldcon. I haven't been back to SA since I was 13.
comments.subject: Maybe we'll see you in San Antonio 2013?
